text: Namadgi) (10.01 a.m.}--I am afraid I start this speech with a certain amount of mirth, given the comments by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), in relation to the personal attributes of certain members. However, it is with considerable concern that I rise in this place today to defend the continued public ownership of Telstra. The Opposition is firmly opposed to the Telstra sell-off, and we will be keeping our commitment to the Australian people at the last federal election to oppose any sale of our publicly owned telecommunications utility. Public ownership of Telstra is vitally important to ensure that all Australians continue to have equal and fair access to the rapidly growing telecommunication and information sectors. It would be an abdication of our responsibility as legislators if we were to let a situation develop whereby we would have in this country an elite group of information rich and a large group of information poor. Not only do the coalition's plans for Australia's largest government owned asset have the potential to undermine universal access to quality telecommunications services, but they may also detract from competition within the telecommunications industry and lead to a significant diminution of opportunity for the local production of telecommunications equipment. There is a whole range of Australian industry developing good technology, dependent upon the feeding line that Telstra supplies. It is absolutely essential for the ongoing development of our industry that Telstra can continue to offer such opportunities. Furthermore, there is cause for concern that this sell-off may also lead to timed local calls. That has been disputed by many, but I do not think it has been examined fully and carefully. I fear that a privatised Telstra would be able to introduce timed local calls by stealth. It They would do this by redefining a local call by making the 'local' area smaller. For example, in my own region, Canberra and Queanbeyan-which is just over the ACT border-currently share a common phone area. In the future, a privati sed Telstra could very easily redefine the local zone by creating two local call zones in this one area. People making telephone calls between Canberra and Queanbeyan could find themselves in the position of going from one local zone to another and therefore being subjected to timed SID rates. It has happened in other cities in the world. There is absolutely no reason why, with a profit margin as your motive, you would not consider such a move. Given the continuing changes in technology and the costs associated with the R&D aspect of technology development-for example, photovoltaics and a whole new range of technologies which are being examined and implemented-the ability of a privatised Telstra to continue to deliver services in an equitable manner without cross-subsidy would be in doubt. When we look at the area of developing technology there is no reason at all for us to believe that a privatised Telstra would automatically be able to afford-or wish to afford-to continue the delivery of service without cross-subsidy. The coalition have argued that the partial privatisation of Telstra is an essential microeconomic reform. I strongly disagree. Privatisation in itself is not micro-economic reform. There is no automatic gain in economic efficiency by transferring ownership from the public to the private sector. It is competition-not privatisation-that will produce efficiencies. The result of this sell-off could in fact be reduction in competition within the telecommunications industry. Telstra has considerable advantage over its competitors at the moment because it owns the network infrastructurethe phone connections to every home in the country. It would be in the interests of a privati sed Telstra to use that natural monopoly power to eliminate its competitors. In stark contrast to the approach of the coalition, the former Labor government instituted sensible reforms in the communications sector. The Labor government introduced competition in service delivery, that is, effective competition between carriersliterally from the telephone socket in the wall. The results of this policy are there for everyone to see. We have seen a massive increase in investment in communications infrastructure. Exports of telecommunications equipment from this country have gone from $200 million to over $1 billion a year. A huge range of services are opening up to consumers. Telstra's customer services have improved dramatically. The whole range of opportunity within this industry has improved enormously. All of these things have occurred as a direct result of the Labor government introducing proper competition in the early 1990s. Telstra did not have to be privatised to achieve these outstanding results. Another aspect of the proposed Telstra privatisation that has been overlooked, or probably ignored, by the government is the difficulties associated with partial privatisation. Should the privatisation go ahead, there would be a fundamental conflict of interest between the minority private shareholders and the government as the majority shareholder. If Telstra is to be purely profit driven-and what private shareholder would expect anything less than that-then it will not be in the company's interest to continue to provide universal service to all Australians; that is, the maintenance of cross-subsidies for rural and regional areas must surely, automatically, be under threat. If Telstra is to continue to provide universal service, it must do so at the expense of higher profit. Again, this is not in the interests of private shareholders. The a conflict of interest between the private shareholder and the government-that is, the constituents; the taxpayers who expect fair access-is evident. The inclusion of performance standards in the Telstra bill will do very little to counter the fact that a privati sed Telstra will not protect the public interest. The inclusion of these standards appears to be more about diverting public attention away from the privatisation issue than any real concern for the performance of the organisation. I draw to the attention of honourable members opposite the potential for a privatised Telstra to place charges on services such as directory assistance. The temptation to do this would be enormous and understandable. The $80 million in revenue that would be obtained from such a move would be very attractive to private shareholders, but it would come at the expense of many-the sight impaired, mobile phone users, the elderly or people like you and me who forget to carry our phone books with us, which is quite simple to do. In a desperate attempt to find something to talk about, the members opposite have tried to argue that because Labor has supported the privatisation of certain government business enterprises in the past then it must automatically support all privatisation. This is not idiotic but also quite an insipid argument. There is a world of difference between the privatisation of Telstra as we are seeing it now and the privatisations in the past of institutions like the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas. We need to put this on record. The Commonwealth Bank is one of four major banks. It services only about 20 per cent of the banking sector in Australia. It does not have anywhere near the level of market power that Telstra has. Furthermore, the government has maintained a degree of regulatory control over the banking industry via the Reserve Bank. Like the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas was also one of many service providers in a competitive marketplace. Qantas has about 50 per cent of the domestic air travel business and under 40 per cent of the international air travel business in and out of Australia. It is only a small proportion of the population who regularly use the services of an airline. Most importantly, both the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas needed injections of federal funds, taxpayers' money, from time to time for capital expenditure. In contrast, Telstra raises all its own investment funds. It is not a drain on the federal Treasury for capital expenditure. The other aspect of this debate is the coalition's shameless linking of their environment package to the sale of Telstra. The members opposite want people to believe that anyone who does not agree with the flogging off of Telstra is anti-environment. They continue to claim the sole right to environmental concern. This is an absolute affront to the majority of the Australian community. It is also a monopoly that the environment does not need and, frankly, is not one that the environment could afford. Members on this side of the House have an extremely proud environmental record. It was the Labor government which stopped the damming of the Franklin River, protected Coronation Hill, promoted the landcare program and created programs such as the save the bush and the one billion trees by 2000 programs. We saw the creation of the Wet Tropics World Heritage area and, what only I consider to be the absolute jewel in the crown, the protection of the Antarctic wilderness, the Great Southern Whale Sanctuary. These are things that we should all be very proud of. How dare the members opposite give the impression that they are the only people in this place or in this country who have any concern for the environment. That is totally misleading and absolutely dishonest. The list of Labor's claims to the environment in the past is very long and very exhaustive. I have named only a few, but they are worth considering. For people outside this place, do not be conned by the line that the coalition government has suddenly discovered and protected the environment. If the coalition really believed in their environment package, they would not need to privatise Telstra to fund it. I note that they were able to find the money needed to placate their business friends on the issue of tariff concessions. It is amazing that they need to sell Telstra to suddenly have a thing for the environment. I find it quite a contradiction. The whole question of the environment, our care for it, our need for its protection and our belief in it is deserving of normal budget consideration. I agree with the previous speaker, the member for Melbourne Ports, when he asks: what next will we see flogged off, what next will we see as an excuse? Make no bones about it, the coalition had planned to sell Telstra. They knew it would be difficult, if not impossible, without a hook upon which to hang it. They also knew they had to dramatically improve their record on the environment. The coalition saw a very natural linking of the two. It is a con job to the people of this country to expect them to believe this extraordinary connection. I condemn the coalition for it. If the coalition wish to sell Telstra, let them stand up and say so and say it honestly for the reasons that they really have. If you truly believe in the environment, put it in your normal budget allocation like you do health, education and all of the other essentials of this country. Don't try to convince us otherwise. In conclusion, I calion all members in this place to think very carefully about the effects on their constituency, particularly the regional and rural people. I am absolutely certain that there are a number of new members opposite, what I would term the-small 'I' - liberal members opposite, who really may not be totally convinced about this. Do not be conned by it; think very carefully about it. Talk to the people on your side and really consider carefully what it is you are pushing. I am going to very proudly vote against this because I know why I am voting against it. You make sure you know why you are voting for it.

text: I rise to support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and to oppose the government's bill to sell Telstra. I think the House and the people listening to this broadcast should be aware of the amendment moved by the member for Werriwa. It states: "the House is of the opinion that the bill should not be proceeded with, for the following reasons: (1) it represents the start of a process leading to the full privatisation of Telstra; (2) it will lead to a loss of jobs, investment and exports, and the bill also fails to establish Australia-first purchasing policy for Telstra; (3) the remittance of profits overseas which will follow enactment will damage Australia's balance of payments; (4) it provides inadequate protection of universal service obligations and preservation of services in regional, rural and remote Australia; (5) the government's failure to bring outer metropolitan telephone zones into the capital city local call zones; (6) the government's failure to fulfil its commitment to establish an ISDN service throughout Australia plus establish A and B share categories to monitor foreign ownership; (7) the failure to preserve ministerial directions and accountability to the parliament for the delivery of Telstra's universal service obligations; (8) there are much better ways of funding environmental programs than selling Australia's major public asset; (9) it represents an ideological obsession with ownership issues instead of focussing on the competitive features of the telecommunications market; (10) at a time of rapid technological change in telecommunications, the public sector should continue to hold a major strategic asset like Telstra to avoid inequity of access and affordability on the so-termed 'information superhighway' ; (11) with the government's recent decision to review the 1997 telecommunications regulations it is inappropriate for the parliament to be considering the sale of Telstra". Those 11 reasons are very good reasons why this parliament should reject the sale of one-third of Telstra. The reality is that the government does not intend to sell one-third of Telstra; it intends to sell all of it. There is not much point just selling one-third of it. If you sell one-third of it, the government loses all control over the company anyway. This is just the first shot across the bows; it will be a salami slice job where one-third goes now, one-third later and one-third after that. Ultimately, the people who own the biggest company in Australia, Telstra-people should understand that Telstra is the biggest business in this country; it is currently owned by every individual taxpayer-will shortly see, if the an present coalition government gets its way, that many parts of it will be owned by overseas investors. The ownership of this very strategic business will move out of the absolute control of Australian hands and move to others. The opposition does not believe that that is something that should be done. The opposition is firmly of the view, as I believe the majority of the Australian people are, that this business should stay in the government's hands. Members of the opposition say that they have a mandate for selling Telstra. If you went through all the obscure highways and byways of the opposition's policy that they ran to the election and on, they will probably say that they have a mandate for everything. When people vote in elections in Australia, they tend to vote for a variety of issues. As my colleague the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) said earlier, they might have even voted for someone because they thought they were attractive. But this is certainly not a policy that is attractive. If you polled all the Australian people and asked them, 'Do you think the government should sell Telstra, yes or no? the resounding answer would be no, because they know that it is an Australian icon and the government is getting rid of that. They know that Telstra provides 90 per cent of the nation's telecommunications services. In some ways they have voted on whether or not they wanted government to get rid of Telstra. In all the ballots that were held about whether people wanted to have Optus or Telstra as their telephone company, the vast majority voted for Telstra. When they were voting for Telstra in those ballots about Optus and Telstra, they were really choosing whether they wanted the government company or the private company. In those ballots, even in Melbourne, where Optus said they were going to do terrifically, they did badly. Optus got a very small market share out of those ballots. Telstra got over 75 per cent of the market share out of those ballots. That was the people specifically saying that they wanted to choose Telstra, the government company, over Optus, the private enterprise company. We have really had a ballot from the Australian people about what they think, but that does not suit the current government, which has this ideological obsession that somehow or other private enterprise is better than government enterprise. The opposition agree that in many areas private enterprise is better, or preferable if is not necessarily better. In some areas there is a need for the government to have an absolute interest. Telecommunications is one of those areas. At present Telstra has a natural monopoly. It is the biggest government owned asset. Telstra's profits after tax in 1994-95 were $1.753 billion and its total value added represents 2.2 per cent of GOP. This is something that is owned by the people and it is the largest business in the country. The reality is that Telstra also has a lot of strategic interest for Australians. It has a lot more interest for Australians than it does for any other country in the world. The Australian population is the most widely dispersed of any of the developed countries in the world. There is a thick band of population around the eastern seaboard, a few nodes in the centre and on the west and a very sparse population spread over the only continental country on earth. Currently, Telstra has provided a service to those people. It has put a direct dial telephone into nearly every house in the country--one of the most remarkable engineering achievements of the 20th century to cover a country like this which has a dispersed population. A private company would not do that because a private company's business is making a profit. The result of Telstra becoming a private company is that the concentration will be on making money for the shareholders and the interest will then go to where the most profit is. The most profit for Telstra is on the eastern seaboard of Australia down to that tip around Melbourne. There is no real profit for it in Tasmania, South Australia, Western Australia or the outback parts of Queensland and the Northern Territory. There is no profitability there for it at all. The directors of any company that is trying to make a profit and has private shareholders have an obligation to maximise the profit for distribution to the shareholders. They will concentrate on those very highly concentrated population areas of Australia. You will then get a two-tier service from this new business. It will be a good service for people who are in the concentrated population areas like Sydney and Melbourne. It will be a terrible it service for people out in the bush. That would be a tragedy for Australia. One of the things the government always said when they were in opposition was that they represented the bush, that the National Party was always there allegedly running the argument for them. The only party that has actually had a very strong view of providing city services for country people has been the Labor Party. We believe that the same sorts of services should be available to all Australians, whether they live in the bush or in the city. In this modem age the most important service is the telecommunications service. It determines whether you are an information rich or information poor society. We have seen some of the snake oil from the present government about how they were going to do something about that. It would be interesting in this debate if the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government (Mr Warwick Smith), who represents the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), would tell the House what they intend to do about their promise to expand the ISDN service to every person in the country. That was one of the promises they made during the election-snake oil sales from the then opposition. Members of the National Party ran around the country saying, 'We're going to do this.' The reality is that they are not. If they sell Telstra, they will be even less scandal. able to expand that service. We would be very interested to hear from the Minister for Communications and the Arts about the time frame he has in place for implementing that electoral promise. Where is he going to get the billions of dollars that this will cost? We would be very interested to hear that. At least if the government still owned Telstra they would be able to get Telstra on the track and doing something about it. But if Telstra is a private company, and if it costs $15,000 or $20,000 to put an ISDN line onto some farm out in the bush, they will say, 'That's fine. It will cost you $15,000 or $20,000.' It will not be the same cost for someone in the city and the current subsidy will go. The government will say, 'Yes, but we're going to put that on the record,' but the reality is that they are not. One part of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa laments the fact that the government will not be accountable for where they are going with the universal service obligation. We are also concerned that this legislation will take away the preserve for ministerial direction and accountability to the parliament for the delivery of Telstra's universal service obligations. If this bill goes through, the minister will not be able to say, 'Quite frankly, you should be doing this out at Gulargambone and you'd better get on and do it,' because he will have no say over this business anymore. We will be in the ridiculous position where the people will own, at least in the first instance, two-thirds of the business. The person who will own the share will probably be the Minister for Communications and the Arts or the Minister for Finance. He will hold the shares for the two-thirds of the representation but under this bill will not be able to direct them. So the people who will in fact own this business and determine the fate of this business will not be the Australian people anymore; it will be the private shareholders. By selling one per cent, two per cent, 30 per cent or any of this business, the government loses all control over the business. That is a The opposition says that we should maintain this company in the hands of the Australian people because of those very significant reasons. The government says to us, 'You believed in privatisation. You sold off these other government assets.' But it is very important that people realise the difference between selling off the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas and why the government should keep control, keep ownership in total, of Telstra. As I said earlier, Telstra provides nearly 90 per cent of Australia's telecommunications services. The Commonwealth Bank serviced only about 20 per cent of the bank sector in Australia. Qantas had about 50 per cent of the domestic air travel business and under 40 per cent of the international air travel business in and out of Australia, and only a very small proportion of Australians regularly fly. Both the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas needed injections of cash from the government from time to time to expand their business. The reality with Telstra is that it makes massive profits for the government. As I said earlier, Telstra's profit in the last financial year was $1.75 billion, and it raises all its own investment funds. It is not a drain on the Treasury for capital expenditure, as Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank were from time to time. Unlike Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, Telstra provides an established world-class telecommunications network to all Australians-not just to those who want to bank with the Commonwealth Bank or to those who want to fly overseas or around Australia-at a reasonable cost. Telstra also makes very substantial contrian butions to the government through income tax. Last year it paid $649 million to the federal government. It does not minimise tax payments, as private companies do. Once the government privatises Telstra, it will able to utilise all sorts of legitimate tax minimisation mechanisms, which will ensure that the return to the people through the tax cut will be even less. Another very important issue that I would like to mention in the few moments left to me is the effect the sale of Telstra will have on the Australian electronics industry. The minister will go on with a lot of cant about how Telstra has always bought from Australto ians and how Telstra will continue to buy from Australians. If that is so, we would interested to hear the government's response to the proposition made by the member for (Time expired) Werriwa that the government should legislate for that. We believe that a buy Australia policy for Telstra should be legislated for. At present, over 70 per cent of Telstra's equipment, materials and services is pursecond chased from Australian firms, big and small. Telstra is the biggest buyer in the country. privatised Telstra would not be required to maintain such purchasing policies. The same thing would then happen with Telstra as happened with Optus, where Optus's partports ners-North American telephone companiescountry are purchasing their equipment overseas. Telstra will have pressure from its shareholdto expect. ers to maximise their profits, saying that Telstra should buy wherever in the world it most competitive to buy. That would put the electronics industry at great risk. That industry has been one of the very great success stories in Australia over the last 15 or 20 years. We have seen the develthat opment of an industry which gives us a edge. We have seen an industry develop second which has relied, in many instances, on getting its start through either defence Telstra contracts. Telstra is one customers of the Australian electronics industry and, with that pressure from shareholders, that will go. The government should be sincere about this, recognise that the electronics industry is important part of Australian industry, and legislate to provide that a minimum of 70 per cent of Telstra's equipment, materials and its services be purchased from Australian companies. That is fair and reasonable. If the be present system is working well and there was bipartisan support for it, let us put it in the legislation to make sure that the new owners of Telstra do this. Everyone thought that the owners of Optus were going to do this and they did not. So, for all the reasons outlined by the member for Werriwa, we should not be passing this bill as it is. The opposition has a number of specific amendments that it intends move at the consideration in detail stage of the bill. We hope the government will accept be those amendments because they will make it a better bill and it will be better for Australia.

text: No. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop), who formerly had some interest in the area of privatisation but perhaps has less these days, certainly has failed to deliver to the public a policy in this area of privatisation which will actually meet the demands of this country into the next century. The reality is that this bill is probably the worse of all worlds for telecommunications ownership. The bill does not pass the appropriate tests which the public of Australia will come to impose on this government on the way in which its ideologically driven decisions in this area actually supplant public interest. The reality is that Telstra is not the same many other areas of government ownership which have been privatised in the past. Telstra is in quite a different category, as the debacle over the joint venture agreement during the election campaign showed. The then opposition, now the government, regarded as quite unacceptable the joint venture arrangements between Telstra, IDM and others over information technology sourcing. It regarded those arrangements as quite untenable. It said that they reflected a part-privatisation of Telstra the then government, which in reality turned out to be quite incorrect. It was simply a better way of Telstra doing business, and the government now has been forced to concede that point. The government has now been forced to allow that to proceed. Of course, that exposes the sham which we saw during the election campaign when that indeed was said to be unacceptable. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), while in opposition during the campaign, ruled out those very measures which they now endorse as appropriate business practice. I think that draws the distinction between the opposition and the government on this matter. We are prepared to support privatisation, commercialisation, where that represents sound public policy and sound ultimate business practice. That is not the case in the example of Telstra, as members of the government would well know. There are substantial differences between the sale of Qantas, the sale of the Commonwealth Bank and the sale of Telstra. I think some of those differences have already been well highlighted. They relate to the market dominance of Telstra which is to be contrasted with the position of the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas. Indeed, while Qantas has some half of the domestic market and a substantial part of the international market, it does not service a very substantial part of the Australian community. I think some five per cent of Australians fly regularly. While the Commonwealth Bank served a very useful and significant purpose to be publicly owned in the early part of its life as cycle, that did not apply at the time the Labor government privatised the Commonwealth Bank. Circumstances had changed dramatically. We used the opportunity of public ownership to create the environment in which the Commonwealth Bank could flourish initially and then, when it was no longer necessary or essential for it to be in public ownership, the opportunity was taken to privatise it. It is, of course, a very important part of our banking fraternity but not a dominant part of it. It is by no longer critical to the public ownership test. But Telstra is quite different. Not only is that the dominant carrier to the extent of some 90 per cent of telecommunications traffic in this country, but it is also in a transition and a deregulation phase. One of the important parts of the Labor government's telecommunications policy over the last decade was to ensure that the telecommunications industry was properly deregulated in a phased and measured way, the public performance standards were there and the service delivery was there but that the benefits of competition flowed through to the public. Telstra, and indeed the whole industry, is still in that transition phase. It is still pre-1997. We do not yet have the complete picture of where an open telecommunications industry will take this country. Telstra, Optus, Vodafone and others which will be entering the market shortly are not yet in a mature and settled position in relation to their industry. Quite clearly there are many issues still outstanding in that dimension of the deregulation of the telecommunications industry, issues which are quite properly still to be settled. I understand that the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston, has tom up the initial draft post-1997 regulatory bill and is starting afresh. That might be his right as a minister, but I think it indicates just where we are in this process. There is still a very long way to go. To impose on the telecommunications industry-and indeed its dominant carrier, Telstra-at this stage in the deregulation process the additional uncertainty which part-privatisation will bring, I think is a very negative aspect of the overall approach that this government brings to telecommunications policy. For one thing it completely ignores the vital industry development aspects of the telecommunications industry itself. As a recent Bureau of Industry Economics report indicated: Australia has a long tradition in the manufacturing . of TE. Much of this industry originally developed under the protective umbrella of the Postmaster General and later Telecom. A number of firms mentioned in interviews with BIE that Telecom acted as an effective leading-edge customer, with stringent technical and quality specifications, stimulating the development of local capabilities. In line with the general industrial restructuring deregulation of the telecommunications market, this section of the industry is becoming increasingly internationally competitive and export oriented. I think that illustrates very nicely just what role the Postmaster-General's Department and ultimately Telecom and Telstra have played in ensuring that Australia has a viable, active and effective telecommunications industry export regime. We have been able to develop a substantial export market under the guidance of Telecom and Telstra to ensure that local firms know exactly where they stand in this market, that they have to meet the highest world best practice standards in the provision of this equipment, and that they have a leading edge purchasing authority to guide them in this very difficult process of becoming world competitive. They have taken on that challenge and they have succeeded. In 1983, some 10 or 12 years ago, the industry had very minimal exports of about $50 million a year. However, it is now up to nearly $1 billion a year and heading beyond that. I think the reality of that transition over the last decade, from $50 million in exports to over $1 billion in exports, is very significant and shows us just what an important role Telstra has played in guiding that industry, which is vital to Australia's future development in this region, through its formative stages. To impose privatisation, to impose deregulation, and to impose them both together and therefore remove the industry deVelopment and national interest constraints that Telstra has always operated under, will be very damaging to that emerging industry, one which is set to take Australia as part of the overall information technology and telecommunications industries into the year 2000. It has put that very much at risk. It is worth noting that the total IT and telecommunications business in this country will be worth of the order of $10 billion by the year 2000. That prediction is a very substantial one. It shows the magnitude of the combined IT and telecommunications industries, where they have still to go and what potential they have, and this government puts much of that at risk. That is very sad for and Australia, very sad for a vital sunrise industry which has contributed so much to our export growth and which has the potential to make this country a leading edge exporter of IT and telecommunications. The government has done that by creating this climate of uncertainty about telecommunications and information technology and, in many ways, for industry in general. The harsh reality of that was brought out by something I read recently in the Financial Review. A leading information technology industry representative said that the impact of the government's proposals on the withdrawal of the tariff schemes and many of the other things that they have done since they took office 'is very uncertain'. He said: One thing people were comfortable with under the previous Government was that you knew what the policy was. That is quite instructive about the way in which this government has introduced a climate of risk and uncertainty into the public and private sectors of this country which we did not see under the previous government. I will remind you of the last phrase: . . . under the previous Government . . . you what the policy was. Unfortunately, that is no longer the case following the changes which this government has already started to implement in relation to telecommunications and information technology. It has promised to withdraw $1 billion in capital expenditure over the next triennial period. That has placed the IT industry under severe threat and created a great amount of uncertainty in the industry. The partprivatisation of Telstra will do the same in the vital telecommunications industry area. Meanwhile, question marks hang over important tax concessions, such as the research and development 150 per cent tax concession, which has been vital to establishing our export oriented research and development industries and to ensuring our large domestic base in R&D. The question mark that hangs over that concession-ministers tell us that we will have to wait till 20 August to find out-also creates the kind of uncertainty which the extract I just quoted to the House refers to. There are question marks over the partnerships for development program, fixed tenn arrangements, the R&D grants which the previous government put in place, and the multi-media scheme promoted by the member for Dobell (MrLee) when he was the minister for communications, and by the former Prime Minister. Those question marks do not ensure a good result for Australian industry, particularly in the vital high-tech areas. Stability is one of the things that small business and smalland medium-sized enterprises need more than anything else. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talks about issues like unfair dismissal laws and other red tape questions-those things have . their impact, for sure-but not about the fact that smalland medium-sized industries need stability in policy making more than anything else. They need the kind of stability which will ensure that tariff arrangements and tax concessions stay in place and which will deliver the low inflation and solid growth that the previous government delivered. That is the kind of stability those businesses need above knew all else to ensure that they grow and flourish. The Howard government, unfortunately, has taken all of those things away from them. That is a very sad commentary on a government which has been in office for such a brief time. The industry also needs to note that this part-privatisation is quite possibly the worse of all worlds for it. If this bill makes its way through all stages of the parliament, Telstra will be one-third privatised. I suspect that that outcome will be followed only by full privatisation, perhaps in a phased program, perhaps not. The Prime Minister has given a commitment that that will not occur during the life of this parliament. But while I assume that is one commitment that will be honoured-no doubt one of few in the long tenn-the reality still is that Telstra will be one-third privatised, if this bill is successful, for a substantial period of time. That will mean that the government is still in control of two-thirds of the company. But governments do not make good majority shareholders. Once you sell one share in Telstra you have effectively turned the company over to the one-third private ownership criteria. The private owners are the ones who will really control Telstra. Government, when it is only a majority public shareholder in what is a privately controlled company, is never in a good position to ensure accountability and the development of the national interest. The government will not be in a position to direct the company. It will not be in a position to use its two-thirds voting share to oppress the one-third minority shareholders. It is the commercial shareholders, including as it will foreign owners, whose interests will predominate. The ability to impose checks and balances on that foreign ownership is further diluted by the government's abandonment of the promise to have A and B class shares to ensure that there is an effective manner of holding the overseas shareholders accountable for their prescribed limit in the company. Neither will there be the opportunity for the minister to direct the company, nor for national interest to play a very substantial role in the newly privati sed Telstra. Why should foreign owners allow Telstra to continue to provide development assistance to Australian start-up companies? In many cases those shareholders might be competitors of Telstra. They might be overseas interests with conflicting requirements for Telstra when it comes to exports to the Asia-Pacific areas, to India, and to other overseas developing markets. They will be almost certainly exerting pressure on Telstra to source its suppliers from elsewhere. Why would Telstra continue to buy products in the Australian market when it can buy them cheaper from overseas on the back end of an AT&T, British Telecom, Sprint, Mercury or MCI contract? All of those things will be out there in the global marketplace. Why should Telstra continue to focus on the best practice in the Australian market when those other pressures will be very firmly exerted by the board of Telstra and the private shareholders' representatives on that board? That is the harsh reality of a one-third privatised Telstra. It is neither public nor private. It suffers from the worse constraints of both. To impose this change on the industry and on that particular company during a period of deregulation is perhaps the worse possible outcome in that regard. I have always had a very strong interest in one particular aspect of the future development of the telecommunications industry here and that is the ISDN system. The former minister for communications would be well aware of my interest and no doubt the current minister will become so. The reality is that ISDN became something of an election issue, or an election token, when the Prime Minister, then Leader of the Opposition, promised the National Farmers Federation and all other Australians through his communications policy that ISDN would be at every front door, available on demand to anyone who wanted to make that request of Telstra and pay the market fee. Like many members of this House, many householders would not know exactly what ISDN is and that it is something they should be demanding. The Prime Minister promised it to them and they should look very closelyMr Brereton interjecting

I ask them to also examine this question: is this, in reality, the technology which they want to take rural Australia and outer metropolitan Australia into the next century with? The reality is that ISDN was very important in this country 10 years ago; jt was leading edge technology then. Is it still leading edge technology? Certainly not. The reality is that to be at the leading edge in the next century you will need broadband services at your door and you will need the optical fibre with a capacity of an order of magnitude greater than ISDN can deliver. While ISDN will make a very good computer data link for some people out in the rural areas, it will not provide them with state-of-the-art multimedia and broadband services. If the government is to meet its commitment to rural Australia and regional Australia to ensure that they are at the leading edge of broadband and data delivery services, then it needs to make a commitment in relation to broadband and not continue to pretend that ISDN will deliver these services to the bush. The reality is that it was a good leading edge service some years ago. Telstra did not pursue that service in the way which I personally think that it should have; but the reality is that ISDN is moving past its prime and will be a very ordinary service over the next few years and that people will really be looking for broadband services. Just what the reality of that promise is, we still need to know. What is the reality of local call areas and the local call fee? Untimed local calls are guaranteed, but what about local call areas? What about the universal service obligation? How are we to enforce the accountability on the minister when he is no longer responsible to this parliament for Telstra? That is the harsh reality. That accountability will disappear once the minister no longer has the power to direct Telstra. That, I think, is the most important aspect of this. Other colleagues have talked about the way in which the environment should not be linked to the sale of Telstra, and I strongly endorse those remarks. I want to tum now to some particular issues. Universal service obligations issues were raised in nearly every contribution by the opposition. The claim has broadly been made that there is a watering down of the universal service obligation, which is an obligation in legislation that you equalise the cost of calls across the nation because the new section in the Telstra Corporation Act8CM-refers to the universal service obligation being fulfilled 'as economically and efficiently as practicable'. In fact, the provision in the bill that has been referred to by the opposition is identical to the policy objectives spelt out in paragraph 287(1)(b) of the existing Telecommunications Act, which was passed in this place in 1991 with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) as the then minister for communications and me, ironically, as the opposition spokesman on communications. We both agreed that that was an eminently sensible piece of legislation, at that stage, in relation to that particular clause and that clause is preserved in this piece of legislation. The existing provisions will be strengthened by reaffirming in the Telstra act that the universal service obligation is not affected by the dilution of public ownership in Telstra. The current provision in section 287 of the act that provides for the universal service obligation to be fulfilled as efficiently and economically as practicable-it has been there since 1991, as I say-simply makes it clear that there is no room for complacency in exploring better ways to deliver telecommunications services. Indeed, the contribution of the previous speaker, the member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans), was thoughtful in terms of the assessment of the technologies-the very point this section enables us to pursue-in that there are emerging technologies which make it possible to deliver these services with even greater efficiency and with price benefits for consumers. We want to make sure that the act is drawn in such a way as to have that flexibility to pursue that broader principle of USO. The bill does not limit the operation of the universal service obligation in any way. Section 288 of the Telecommunications Act 1991 will continue to guarantee reasonable access by all Australians to the standard telephone service. The government is also to commence a review to examine whether the definition of the standard telephone service should be upgraded. Many of us who follow these issues know that that would be a very timely review. The further claim has been made that with Telstra in partial private ownership the usa will not be able to be delivered over time. That is simply not true. The government is committed to universal service and carriers are and will continue to be required to provide and fund universal service obligations. It has also been alleged and suggested that privatisation will lead to an increase in cost for telephone connections and calls. There was a rollcall of electorates for which relevant costs were cited. That was tried during the election campaign without success. Clearly, it is designed to generate some angst amongst rural and regional communities. It was not accepted during the election campaign. It will not be accepted now. This is an amendment to keep the Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), honest in the light of his election commitment to provide the ISDN fast data link throughout Australia by 1 July 1997. This was a clear commitment provided by the Prime Minister to the National Farmers Federation and, we understand, the key commitment by which the National Party agreed to the privatisation of Telstra. Every National Party member in this place should be seriously concerned that the government is backing away from its commitment on the ISDN and that it has not made the ISDN provision an integral part of this legislation. There is no doubt that the Prime Minister gave that commitment to the National Farmers Federation. In his speech of 21 November last year the member for Bennelong said: Today I announce that a Coalition Government will require Telstra to offer all of its customers who have lines connected to digital exchanges with access to ISDN as a standard service. ... these initiatives will mean that, by mid-I997, some 97 per cent of business and household customers should have access to enhanced phone services such as call waiting, call diversion, itemised billing and advanced voice mail services as well as an on-line services delivery system that is more than 10 times faster than the existing analogue technology. It was that commitment to the bush that seduced the National Party into agreeing to the privatisation of Telstra. It was that commitment to regional Australia that convinced members of the National Party that they should be supporting the privatisation of this major public asset. NOES Mr ANDREN (Calare) (1.13 p.m.}-It is with great pride that I address this House as an independent member of the 38th Parliament since Federation. Had it not been for the dedicated help and encouragement of my supporters and family, particularly my wife Jenny and sons, Greg and Josh, this moment would not have been possible. I must begin with congratulations to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the coalition on their resounding win in the recent election. I also congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, and the Second Deputy Speaker, Mr Jenkins. Please pass on my congratulations also to the Speaker. May we all give you the support you deserve to achieve the fairest possible debate in the parliamentary period ahead. Five Independents will figure in that debate. According to my research, that is the greatest number of non-aligned Independents elected to one parliament since Federation. The last PAIRS parliament benefited from the wisdom of Independent Ted Mack, to whom lowe a deep debt of gratitude for his advice and support. I hope to contribute as he did to advancing the cause of democratic parliamentary representation in this chamber. I have heard encouraging words in recent days about a commitment to a better, fairer and more democratic parliament than has occurred in recent history. I believe the electorate has also spoken finnly on this issue in the recent election. Rather than a ringing endorsement of the policies of the new government, the electorate rejected a Labor government and a Prime Minister seen to be out of touch and arrogant. Where there was a convincing third option for voters, they took it and elected five Independents and increased the support for the Democrats in the Senate. In a world that is becoming more confusing, more threatening, far more violent and less personal by the day, people need leadership from politicians who will hear their calls regardless of the political implications. Such a test of our resolve to create a more caring, less violent Australia must surely be a unanimous commitment to uniform gun laws when police ministers meet tomorrow in the wake of the Port Arthur massacre. And anticipating less than unanimous support from the states, I call too for an early referendum to test whether Australians want the Commonwealth to take control of gun supply and ownership-and the making and distribution .of violent videos. Despite some academic claims to the contrary, my extensive media background suggests that brutal behaviour and the video pornography of violence are closely linked. Lest one side or the other in this place believes it has a mortgage on common sense, might I warn that the traditional role of parties in Australian politics is under strong challenge. There is a growing awareness in the electorate that honest, effective representawhere tion of constituents' interests can be achieved through channels other than political parties. Inflexible ideology on either side will bring swift retribution. People want fair and reasonable government, no domination by one school of thought whether it be union or rationalist economics. People expect government participation and support in their lives, as much as they respect the value of private enterprise for fair return, provided it both rewards the entrepreneur and is beneficial to the common wealth. That brings me to some of the issues of national importance relevant to my area' of . central western New South Wales, issues involving both private and government responsibilities that I propose to pursue during this parliamentary term. Calare is a rural division extending from Oberon in the southeast, to Yeoval in the north-west, to Eugowra in the south-west and to tiny Bylong in the north-east. It was at Bylong a week or so ago where I gladly lost some money for local charity on several long priced entrants in the annual mouse races, surely the epitome of rural ingenuity. Calare contains the local government areas of Lithgow, Oberon, Rylstone, Bathurst, Blayney, Evans, Cabonne and parts of Wellington, with major industries including education, timber, mining, cement, wool top making, whitegoods, food and pet food manufacturing, tourism to a veritable gold mine of attractions and, of course, farming, especially fruit growing and grazing. However, the viability of much of this industry is under threat from short-sighted economic policies. Of grave concern is the breakdown of infrastructure in the regions. Unless national governments inject capital into regional Australia or offer greater incentives for private capital to take a larger role in the regions then the smaller towns, and the larger centres, are at grave risk of further economic decline. We need to inject far more into local government by way of untied grants for projects that are crucial to small and large communities. By that I mean projects such as the Eugowra sewerage augmentation scheme a struggling and ageing rural community cannot sustain even the most basic of infrastructure, rights that most Australians take for granted. While mining is a seductive job deliverer to a depressed rural economy, we must not assume that quarrying our resources is the only key to regional development. We must measure the long-term benefits and retain and strengthen a federal environment review process to oversee all mining or resource extraction that makes a significant impact on the national environment. I do not believe the parochial interests of state governments, and particularly local governments, are far enough removed from such projects to enable objective assessment. Economic rationalism and downsizing of government involvement in the economy, a philosophy to which the three major parties in this country are captive, is counterproductive in country areas like Orange where public sector jobs have been slashed without regard for the type of service delivered by those former public servants. In this case in Orange it was state agriculture department staff. Those people provide an essential service for the economic well-being of farmer clients. Nor does it take into account the money those forgone salaries inject into the local economy. At a federal level we see the planned removal of the Australian Taxation Office from regional centres, ostensibly because a more cost efficient, electronic service is available. This is the brave new world of public service where the elderly, the computer illiterate, the struggling business operator, fanner, the tax student and the tax agent are all expected to seek advice via a toll-free This has nothing to do with public service, it has much to do with ignoring the real requirements of regional Australia. That is the service infrastructure under threat. On the other hand, we see the deliberate dismantling of publicly owned concrete infrastructure. With the demise of the New South Wales branch rail system over the past decade, the western rail line from Sydney to Broken Hill is a national asset which is now under grave threat. For years the responsibility for the line has been buck-passed between federal and state governments, and downgraded to the extent that it is now a disincentive to private users. Meanwhile, the multibillion dollar trucking business has grown on the back of this neglect of rail, causing massive road damage to systems not designed for the size or frequency of such heavy freight cartage. The more enlightened trucking operators want to integrate road and rail operations, and movers of bulk materials, such as CSR Oberon, tell me that it would be far more cost efficient to transport export products straight to the wharves by rail. The government is reluctant to meet the commercial users halfway by guaranteeing fair access to the rail network. Indeed, the madness of this approach dictates that the community service obligations of governments are virtually eliminated. Nowhere are the costs of trucks on roads-or the absence of trains on tracks carrying bulk and hazardous freight-factored into the bottom line. Can we afford not to maintain the existing national rail network in this country? Indeed, can we afford not to expand it, thus maintaining rail and freight jobs in regional centres along the way? Unless the Commonwealth government re-enters the infrastructure business, this country will never develop to its full potential, and most of that potential lies in regional Australia in areas like Cal are. A substantial re-regulation of the financial system is required to ensure that essential capital flows into the public sector to serve the the public good. Private lending institutions create credit for private, often unproductive, line. profit-credit that is also responsible for importation of consumer goods at the expense of local jobs. We should restore parliament's right to create national credit for national projects which become part of the nation's wealth as assets. We should also tax foreign exchange transactions and legislate to access the $60 billion of Australian superannuation funds that should be helping to develop this country, and not being invested offshore. Private enterprise will be a partner in developing regional Australia if the infrastructure is in place. I am not talking about 150 per cent tax write-offs for investors in vineyard projects. I am talking about public credit like government bonds created to maintain income, positive infrastructure such as our transcontinental rail links or a nationally funded Great WesternMid Western Highway with rail-road container interchanges, or a Parkes inland freight airport. I notice that the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) is in the chamber. I appreciate his presence. This latter project, while outside my electorate, will have a huge impact on industry in our area, and is of major national importance. Yet this scheme may also be killed off by the economic rationalists before it gets off the ground. From the briefings I have had with the Inland Marketing Corporation, which is overseeing and promoting this regional agricultural development project, I believe it is a national value-adding asset without peer. It would not only provide an international airfreight airport to deliver overseas markets, particularly in Asia, but it would tie in with a revitalised main western rail line and a north-south Newell Highway, to create a truly integrated rail-road-air cargo network. Many hundreds of jobs-potentially thousands---<:ould be generated by this multifaceted agricultural project that would ensure we became a reliable supplier of the cleanest, freshest and greenest foodstuffs to those emerging tiger economies to the north, and beyond in Europe. I can foresee an extension of this project an international passenger airport, revitalising the regional airline industry, and complemented by a very fast train from Parkes to Sydney. It is an airport complex which most in western New South Wales really want, believe it or not. Why throw billions at an airport in western Sydney that few want? Let us become creative and, I believe, truly economically rational by developing our transport infrastructure to meet the requirements of the new century and, at the same time, help regenerate regional Australia, from which our agricultural and mineral wealth is derived. We cannot leave the regions to the forces of the level playing field. We need to protect our manufacturing plants, like Email at Orange and the Commonwealth-owned Australian Defence Industries in Lithgow. We need to protect emerging value-adding industry in regional areas, especially wool textiles. Email's market share is threatened by tariff concession cuts to imports, despite the changes in the last few days; while the 100 per cent Commonwealth owned ADI is chasing diminishing arms contracts when it has the capacity to train young locals in metal manufacturing of a range of import replacing components. Returns to farmers have been negative in seven of the past 10 years and the National Party has sold out its constituency by following the Liberal-Labor economic rationalist level playing field path. Our national competition policy is becoming so efficient that wool growers are competing against their own product in the marketplace and the level playing field is so level that Orange district fruit juice cannot compete against the importproduce rapidly to ed product. The regional social infrastructure too has suffered dramatically as we head down this brave new world of 'winners only survive' economics. Unfortunately, the less than clever have no role in this new world. Where are the jobs for the 50 per cent perhaps of people, who, through no fault of their own, find they are on the wrong side of the normal distribution curve of intelligence and ability in this so-called clever age? Where do they fit in? We once had a manufacturing base like to ADI at Lithgow that involved many of these people in the work force as process workers and doing the manual jobs. Where have they gone? We cannot retrain most of the older displaced workers. There is nothing for the young who are not clever or lucky except a series of work skills programs. We have a national youth unemployment rate around 30 per cent, if you can believe the figures, and an overall unemployment rate officially about eight per cent and sure to go up. The figures are almost the same as they were when the coalition handed over the reins of government to Labor in 1983. Whatever the job creation in that time, it has not provided for the notso-clever who are the victims of the modem competition at all costs, economic rationalism, survival of the fittest regime. If we do not devise ways of providing meaningful employment for these people, we are socially doomed. We cannot bemoan the anti-social behaviour of those whose own society and economic system cannot provide them with a job or a life beyond mindless videos. We have a rampant cancer in our society. The inability to provide gainful employment for our young is a major cause. We need to be far more creative in our work programs. We need to provide not 26-week work skilling, but perhaps three-year long, two days a week commitments. Participants can be employed in projects that would enable a long-term belonging to a work team and a venture that would yield obvious results. I recently saw long-term unemployed coming off a project near Molong-nowhere near completed-a landcare project that could have a permanent employment team, that certainly would benefit from a long-term commitment. But no, they had to move back to the welfare queues with a certificate to make room for the next group. Of course, they cannot qualify for a similar project for another 18 months. It is soul destroying. I have heard from some of these people. They wish they had never started-rather than to have experienced the team work, to have part completed the job and then to be abandoned. Unless we review our economic policies, we will never again approach full employment. There are at least one million people in this country who want to work and who cannot. Surely there is something wrong with the system that created this. Young people in particular with no real prospects of productive employment not only bitterly resent the society that cannot share its wealth with them but also are being constantly bombarded by media messages telling them how successful they should be. There are only winners. Anger sets in, and if you happen to be black in this country, particularly in regional Australia, your race marginalises you even further. The result, in many cases, is violence, selfforeign abuse through drugs and alcohol, vandalism, and a widening gulf between the haves and the have-nots-between the 'me too' class and the 'up you' class. Is this the legacy of the rational new world economy, of the level playing field? Is this really the country with the greatest natural assets and resources in world? Is this the price we pay for international competitiveness by downsizing, corporatising, privati sing, adopting world best practice and handing manufacturing over to the countries with the cheapest labour? Where, I ask, is this mythical country where world best practice is practised? Did the economic zealots who created a world series market to be played for on this level playing field consider those in our society who cannot even make the bench for this game or any future match? We in regional Australia need help from central government for the regions to rebuild their industries and we need a new consensus whereby all states cooperate to highlight a regional development agenda that would involve a sharing of investment. Unless we get this state cooperation in the interests of the nation, our limited resources will be wasted and the opportunities lost in mindless political struggles between the states. While on the subject of states, the only piece of economic rationalism we should adopt, I believe, is to rationalise them right out of existence. If we are serious about constitutional reform, let us look seriously at the costs caused by the duplication-and duplicity--of the states. Stronger regional government with roughly equal populations to administer and an equal share of the federal tax take is the only logical way we should go in any constitutional reform. The current republic debate is a furphy, given the substantial reforms needed to really make us nationally cooperative and economically efficient. Such reform would even out opportunity and bring government closer to the people, making it so much more accountable. It would enable us to focus on a cooperative national goal rather than state of origin footie matches. As we develop new national infrastructure, funded by national credit and not debt to interests, let us also hold on to the remaining shareholding of the publicly owned assets we now retain. The folly of selling off our silverware to pay debts would be laughable were it not so serious. The latest folly is the partial the privatisation of Telstra, which I believe can only penalise my constituents and the nation. It sounds a bit like part-pregnant, doesn't it? The opposition, the former government, is equally guilty because it too has gone down the same path in selling off Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, opposing the Telstra privatisation only when it became politically fruitful to do so. I do not believe any serious investor will want part of Telstra; they will want the lot. Can you imagine Murdoch wanting only the front paddock of the most productive lucerne flat property in Australia? I believe that we should fund the environment by hanging on to Telstra and we should legislate so that $250 million of that $1 billion per year is dedicated to the environment. Retain the ownership of that great organisation and it can bankroll the environment to infinity. To my father and mother, both deceased, thanks for the strength and guidance that brought me here to this place. May my colleagues in the 38th Parliament of Australia embrace the feeling my parents had for this country and represent all Australians: those with skills and those without, those with means and those without. Unless we provide for all, with real opportunities and not just handouts, then the profits, the growth and dividends we create are a fraud, a mirage.
